messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Approximability results for the ùëù-centdian and the converse centdian problemsAn extended abstract of this paper was presented in the 18th International Conference Information and Knowledge Engineering (IKE 2019). This work was supported in part by the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan under Contract MOST 105-2221-E-845-002, 107-2115-M-845-001 and 110-2221-E-845-001.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Given an undirected graph G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) with a nonnegative edge length function and an integer pùëùp, 0<p<|V|0ùëùùëâ0<p<|V|, the pùëùp-centdian problem is to find pùëùp vertices (called the centdian set) of VùëâV such that the eccentricity plus median-distance is minimized, in which the eccentricity is the maximum (length) distance of all vertices to their nearest centdian set and the median-distance is the total (length) distance of all vertices to their nearest centdian set. The eccentricity plus median-distance is called the centdian-distance. The purpose of the pùëùp-centdian problem is to find pùëùp open facilities (servers) which satisfy the quality-of-service of the minimum total distance (median-distance) and the maximum distance (eccentricity) to their service customers, simultaneously. If we converse the two criteria, that is given the bound of the centdian-distance and the objective function is to minimize the cardinality of the centdian set, this problem is called the converse centdian problem. In this paper, we prove the pùëùp-centdian problem is NP-Complete. Then we design the first non-trivial brute force exact algorithms for the pùëùp-centdian problem and the converse centdian problem, respectively. Finally, we design two approximation algorithms for both problems.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Genetic algorithm to solve the pùëùp-centre and pùëùp-radius problem on a network",
        "Probabilistic analysis of a relaxation for the k-median problem",
        "Local search heuristics for kùëòk-median and facility location problems",
        "Approximation algorithms for selecting network centers",
        "How to allocate network centers",
        "Centdian computation in cactus graphs",
        "Theory and Graphs and its Applications",
        "Spread of information in a social network using influential nodes",
        "On multicast path finding algorithms",
        "A greedy heuristic for the set-covering problem",
        "Towards a theory of domination in graph",
        "Introduction to Algorithm, 3rd edition",
        "Network and Discrete Location: Models Algorithms and Applications",
        "What you should know about location modeling",
        "Facility Location Applications and Theory, 2nd edition",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "Efficient computation of delay-sensitive routes from one source to all destinations",
        "Clustering to minimize the maximum intercluster distance",
        "Simpler analyses of local search algorithms for facility location",
        "Optimal distribution of switching centers in a communication network and some related theoretic graph theoretic problems",
        "The location of a center-median convex combination on an undirected tree",
        "Finding minimal center-median convex combination (cent-dian) of a graph",
        "A unified approach to approximation algorithms for bottleneck problems",
        "Various notions of approximations: good, better, best, and more",
        "Finite dominating sets for network location problems",
        "Easy and hard bottleneck location problems",
        "Greedy facility location algorithms analyzed using dual fitting with factor-revealing LP",
        "Approximation algorithms for combinatorial problems",
        "Routing to multiple destinations in computer networks",
        "An algorithmic approach to network location problems I: the pùëùp-centers",
        "An algorithmic approach to network location problems II: the pùëùp-medians",
        "A new polynomial-time algorithm for linear programming",
        "A polynomial algorithm in linear programming (in Russian)",
        "Multicasting for multimedia applications",
        "œµitalic-œµ\\epsilon-approximations with minimum packing constraint violation (extended abstract)",
        "The ratio of optimal integral and fractional covers",
        "Bicriteria network design problems",
        "Facility location and covering problems",
        "A linear time algorithm for connected pùëùp-centdian problem on block graphs",
        "Solving two location models with few facilities by using a hybrid heuristic: a real health resources case",
        "The finite dominating set for the pùëùp-facility centdian network location problem",
        "The generalized pùëùp-centdian on network",
        "A heuristic for the pùëùp-center problem in graphs",
        "Theory of Graphs",
        "Location analysis: a synthesis and survey",
        "A bibliography for some fundamental problem categories in discrete location science",
        "Computing near-optimal solutions to combinatorial optimization problems",
        "Effcient algorithms for the 2-center problems",
        "Improved complexity bounds for center location problems on networks by using dynamic data structures",
        "A polynomial algorithm for the pùëùp-centdian problem on a tree",
        "Location on networks: a survey. Part I: the pùëùp-center and pùëùp-median problems",
        "Introduction to Graph Theory"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Approximability results for the ùëù-centdian and the converse centdian problemsAn extended abstract of this paper was presented in the 18th International Conference Information and Knowledge Engineering (IKE 2019). This work was supported in part by the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan under Contract MOST 105-2221-E-845-002, 107-2115-M-845-001 and 110-2221-E-845-001., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
